questions.question: An athlete tracks how the amount of protein intake per day affects their muscle recovery time. In this study, what is the 'protein intake' called?
questions.explanation: The independent variable is the factor that is deliberately changed or manipulated by the experimenter to observe its effect on the dependent variable (recovery time).

questions.question: A physicist states: 'If the mass of a planet is tripled, then its gravitational pull on a nearby satellite will increase.' Name this stage of the investigation.
questions.explanation: A hypothesis is a testable prediction stated in an 'If...then...' format about the relationship between variables.

questions.question: The mass of a specific helium-3 atom is $0.000000000000000000000000005008\text{ kg}$. Express this mass in scientific notation.
questions.explanation: Move the decimal point 27 places to the right: $0.000000000000000000000000005008 = 5.008 \times 10^{-27}\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: The total energy output of a power plant over a decade is $48,200,000,000,000,000\text{ J}$. Express this energy in scientific notation.
questions.explanation: Move the decimal point 16 places to the left: $48,200,000,000,000,000 = 4.82 \times 10^{16}\text{ J}$.

questions.question: How many significant figures are in the measurement $0.0007060\text{ m}$?
questions.explanation: Leading zeros are not significant. The digits $7$, $0$, $6$, and the trailing $0$ are significant, giving a total of 4 significant figures.

questions.question: Identify which of these is a fundamental (base) quantity in physics: Thermodynamic Temperature, Force, or Kinetic Energy?
questions.explanation: Thermodynamic temperature is one of the seven SI base quantities. Force and kinetic energy are derived quantities.

questions.question: Identify which of these is a derived quantity: Length, Time, or Magnetic Flux Density?
questions.explanation: Magnetic flux density is derived from force, current, and length. Length and time are fundamental quantities.

questions.question: Which of these is a fundamental SI unit: Kilogram (kg), Newton (N), or Joule (J)?
questions.explanation: The kilogram (kg) is the SI base unit for mass. Newton and Joule are derived units.

questions.question: Which of these is a derived SI unit: Second (s), Mole (mol), or Watt (W)?
questions.explanation: The Watt (W) is a derived unit for power ($1\text{ W} = 1\text{ J/s}$). Second and mole are fundamental SI units.

questions.question: A racing drone travels at a speed of $108\text{ km/h}$. Convert this speed to meters per second ($\text{m/s}$).
questions.explanation: To convert from km/h to m/s, divide by $3.6$: $108 \div 3.6 = 30\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A gale-force wind is recorded at a speed of $25\text{ m/s}$. What is its speed in kilometers per hour ($\text{km/h}$)?
questions.explanation: To convert from m/s to km/h, multiply by $3.6$: $25 \times 3.6 = 90\text{ km/h}$.

questions.question: A micro-drill bit has a diameter of $0.00125\text{ m}$. How many millimeters (mm) is this diameter?
A length of copper piping is $3{,}850\text{ mm}$. Express this length in meters.
The width of a classroom door is $92\text{ cm}$. What is this width in meters?
questions.explanation: $1\text{ m} = 100\text{ cm}$, so $92\text{ cm} = 92 \div 100 = 0.92\text{ m}$.

questions.question: A rooftop solar panel has an area of $18{,}000\text{ cm}^2$. Convert this area to square meters ($\text{m}^2$).
A delivery van drives $700\text{ m}$ due North, then immediately turns around and drives $200\text{ m}$ due South. The entire trip takes $100\text{ s}$. Calculate the van's average velocity.
questions.explanation: Displacement is $700\text{ m}$ North minus $200\text{ m}$ South, which equals $500\text{ m}$ North. Average velocity $= \text{displacement} / \text{time} = 500\text{ m} / 100\text{ s} = 5\text{ m/s}$ North.

questions.question: A roller coaster speeds up uniformly from $8\text{ m/s}$ to $32\text{ m/s}$ in $6\text{ s}$. Calculate the magnitude of the roller coaster's acceleration.
questions.explanation: Acceleration is calculated using $a = \frac{v_f - v_i}{t} = \frac{32 - 8}{6} = \frac{24}{6} = 4\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A cyclist brakes for a light, slowing uniformly from $15\text{ m/s}$ to $3\text{ m/s}$ in $4\text{ s}$. Calculate the acceleration of the cyclist, including the correct sign to indicate direction.
questions.explanation: $a = \frac{3 - 15}{4} = \frac{-12}{4} = -3\text{ m/s}^2$. The negative sign indicates that the acceleration is in the direction opposite to the velocity (deceleration).

questions.question: A runner goes $60\text{ m}$ due East and then $60\text{ m}$ due West, returning to the starting line. The entire trip takes $20\text{ s}$. Calculate the runner's average speed and the magnitude of their average velocity.
questions.explanation: Average speed is total distance over time: $\frac{120\text{ m}}{20\text{ s}} = 6\text{ m/s}$. Average velocity is displacement over time: displacement $= 0$ (returns to start), so velocity $= 0\text{ m/s}$.

questions.question: A survey ship travels $12\text{ km}$ due West and then $5\text{ km}$ due South. Calculate the total distance traveled and the magnitude of the ship's displacement from the starting point.
questions.explanation: Total distance is the sum of the path lengths: $12 + 5 = 17\text{ km}$. Displacement is the straight-line distance from start to finish, found using the Pythagorean theorem: $\sqrt{12^2 + 5^2} = \sqrt{144 + 25} = \sqrt{169} = 13\text{ km}$.

questions.question: An escalator moves at a constant speed of $0.75\text{ m/s}$ in a straight line. What type of motion does this describe?
questions.explanation: Constant speed in a straight line indicates uniform motion with zero acceleration.

questions.question: On a displacement-time graph, the line is straight and sloping downward toward the time axis (x-axis). Describe the velocity of the object.
questions.explanation: A straight line with a constant negative slope on a displacement-time graph indicates uniform negative velocity (the object is moving backward at a constant speed).

questions.question: A velocity-time graph shows a horizontal line at $+12\text{ m/s}$. What is the acceleration of the object?
questions.explanation: A horizontal line on a velocity-time graph means the velocity is constant (not changing). Therefore, the acceleration is zero.

questions.question: A crate of oranges is in the back of a truck. When the truck accelerates forward, the crate slides toward the tailgate. Name the property of the crate that is responsible for this.
questions.explanation: Inertia is the tendency of an object to resist changes in its state of motion. The crate tends to stay at rest while the truck accelerates forward, so it slides backward relative to the truck.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the net force required to accelerate a $0.4\text{ kg}$ soccer ball at $35\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Applying Newton's Second Law: $F = ma = 0.4\text{ kg} \times 35\text{ m/s}^2 = 14\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A person pushes a refrigerator with a force of $420\text{ N}$. According to Newton's Third Law, what is the magnitude of the force the refrigerator exerts back on the person?
questions.explanation: Newton's Third Law states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Therefore, the refrigerator exerts a force of $420\text{ N}$ back on the person.

questions.question: Calculate the weight of a $12.5\text{ kg}$ telescope on Earth, where the acceleration due to gravity $g = 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$.
questions.explanation: Weight is given by $W = mg = 12.5\text{ kg} \times 9.8\text{ m/s}^2 = 122.5\text{ N}$.

questions.question: An object weighs $144\text{ N}$ on a planet where the acceleration due to gravity is $12\text{ m/s}^2$. What is the mass of the object?
questions.explanation: From $W = mg$, the mass is $m = \frac{W}{g} = \frac{144\text{ N}}{12\text{ m/s}^2} = 12\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: A $60\text{ kg}$ desk is resting on a horizontal floor. The coefficient of kinetic friction between the desk and the floor is $0.15$. Calculate the force of friction acting on the desk if it is sliding. (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$).
questions.explanation: The friction force is $f = \mu N = \mu mg = 0.15 \times 60 \times 10 = 90\text{ N}$.

questions.question: If the friction force acting on a sliding object is $64\text{ N}$ and the coefficient of kinetic friction is $0.8$, what is the mass of the object? ($g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Using $f = \mu mg$, we solve for mass: $m = \frac{f}{\mu g} = \frac{64}{0.8 \times 10} = 8\text{ kg}$.

questions.question: A $10\text{ kg}$ block is placed on top of a $30\text{ kg}$ sled. A horizontal force of $120\text{ N}$ is applied to the sled. Assuming no friction, calculate the acceleration of the sled and block together.
questions.explanation: The total mass being accelerated is $10\text{ kg} + 30\text{ kg} = 40\text{ kg}$. Using Newton's Second Law, $a = \frac{F}{m} = \frac{120\text{ N}}{40\text{ kg}} = 3\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: Two wagons, one with a mass of $40\text{ kg}$ and the other with a mass of $60\text{ kg}$, are tied together by a rope and pulled by a $250\text{ N}$ force across a frictionless surface. What is the acceleration of the system?
questions.explanation: The total mass is $40 + 60 = 100\text{ kg}$. The acceleration is $a = \frac{F}{m} = \frac{250\text{ N}}{100\text{ kg}} = 2.5\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A floor polisher is pushed across a floor at a constant speed by an applied force of $32\text{ N}$. What is the magnitude of the friction force acting on the polisher?
questions.explanation: Constant velocity means the net force is zero. Therefore, the applied force must exactly balance the friction force: $f_{\text{friction}} = F_{\text{app}} = 32\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A $210\text{ N}$ force pulls a $25\text{ kg}$ object across a surface. The force of friction opposing the motion is $60\text{ N}$. What is the acceleration of the object?
questions.explanation: The net force is $F_{\text{net}} = 210\text{ N} - 60\text{ N} = 150\text{ N}$. Acceleration is $a = \frac{F_{\text{net}}}{m} = \frac{150\text{ N}}{25\text{ kg}} = 6\text{ m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A $300\text{ N}$ horizontal force pushes a $50\text{ kg}$ block, causing it to accelerate at $4.5\text{ m/s}^2$. What is the magnitude of the frictional force acting on the block?
questions.explanation: The net force required to produce the acceleration is $F_{\text{net}} = ma = 50 \times 4.5 = 225\text{ N}$. Since the applied force is $300\text{ N}$, the friction force must be $F_{\text{friction}} = F_{\text{app}} - F_{\text{net}} = 300 - 225 = 75\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A swimmer moves through the water at a constant speed, overcoming $15\text{ N}$ of water resistance and $10\text{ N}$ of internal friction from their body. What is the applied force provided by the swimmer?
questions.explanation: Constant velocity implies zero net force. Therefore, the swimmer's applied force must balance the total resistance: $F_{\text{app}} = 15\text{ N} + 10\text{ N} = 25\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A motor provides a forward force of $1{,}200\text{ N}$. The internal friction force is $350\text{ N}$. If the object moves at a constant velocity, what is the magnitude of the drag?
questions.explanation: At constant velocity, the net force is zero. Therefore, the thrust must equal the sum of the resistive forces: $1{,}200 = 350 + F_{\text{drag}}$, so $F_{\text{drag}} = 1{,}200 - 350 = 850\text{ N}$.

questions.question: The applied force on an object is $550\text{ N}$, and the air drag acting on it is $380\text{ N}$. If the object moves at a constant velocity, what is the magnitude of the mechanical friction?
questions.explanation: For constant velocity, the net force is zero, so the sum of resistive forces must equal the applied force. Therefore, $550 = 380 + f_{\text{friction}}$, so $f_{\text{friction}} = 550 - 380 = 170\text{ N}$.

questions.question: A person catches a medicine ball and moves their hands backward to slow it down to a stop. Is the work done by the hands on the ball positive, negative, or zero?
questions.explanation: The hands exert a force on the ball in the direction opposite to its motion. Since the force and displacement are in opposite directions, the work done by the hands is negative.

questions.question: An electric motor winds up a cable to lift a bucket of water from a well. Is the work done by the motor on the bucket positive, negative, or zero?
questions.explanation: The motor exerts an upward force on the bucket, and the bucket's displacement is also upward. Force and displacement are in the same direction, so the work done by the motor is positive.

questions.question: A $1.5\text{ kg}$ book is sitting on a bookshelf that is $4\text{ m}$ above the floor. Calculate the book's gravitational potential energy relative to the floor. (Use $g = 10\text{ m/s}^2$).
questions.explanation: Gravitational potential energy is given by $GPE = mgh = 1.5\text{ kg} \times 10\text{ m/s}^2 \times 4\text{ m} = 60\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A $0.5\text{ kg}$ hockey puck slides across the ice at a speed of $12\text{ m/s}$. What is its kinetic energy?
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy is calculated using $KE = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{1}{2}(0.5)(12)^2 = 0.25 \times 144 = 36\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A ball has $200\text{ J}$ of gravitational potential energy at the top of a ramp. At the bottom of the ramp, it has $174\text{ J}$ of kinetic energy. How much energy was converted to heat due to friction?
questions.explanation: The energy lost to heat is the difference between the initial potential energy and the final kinetic energy: $200\text{ J} - 174\text{ J} = 26\text{ J}$.

questions.question: A speedboat is accelerating on a flat lake. Describe the changes in its kinetic energy (KE) and gravitational potential energy (PE).
options: KE is increasing; PE is constant
KE is increasing; PE is increasing
KE is constant; PE is constant
KE is increasing; PE is decreasing
questions.explanation: As the speedboat accelerates, its speed increases, so its KE is increasing. Since it is on a flat lake, its height (and thus its PE) is constant.

questions.question: A stone is dropped from a bridge and falls toward the water. Ignoring air resistance, describe the energy transition as it falls.
questions.explanation: As the stone falls, its height decreases (so PE decreases) and its speed increases (so KE increases). Potential energy is being converted into kinetic energy.

questions.question: A helicopter hovers stationary at a height of $500\text{ m}$ above the ground. Describe the state of its kinetic energy (KE) and gravitational potential energy (PE).
options: KE is zero; PE is constant
KE is constant; PE is zero
KE is increasing; PE is decreasing
Both KE and PE are increasing
questions.explanation: Hovering means the helicopter has zero velocity, so its KE is zero. Its altitude is constant, so its PE is constant.

questions.question: An unstretched spring has a length of $22\text{ cm}$. When a mass is hung from it, the spring's total length becomes $27.1\text{ cm}$. Calculate the extension of the spring.
questions.explanation: The extension is the increase in length: $\text{extension} = \text{final length} - \text{original length} = 27.1\text{ cm} - 22\text{ cm} = 5.1\text{ cm}$.

questions.question: A machine uses $5{,}000\text{ J}$ of energy to perform $3{,}500\text{ J}$ of useful work. Calculate the efficiency of the machine.
questions.explanation: Efficiency is the ratio of useful work output to energy input, expressed as a percentage: $\left(\frac{3{,}500}{5{,}000}\right) \times 100\% = 70\%$.

questions.question: Calculate the total resistance of three resistors with resistances $14\,\Omega$, $26\,\Omega$, and $50\,\Omega$ when they are connected in series.
questions.explanation: For resistors in series, the total resistance is the sum of the individual resistances: $R_{\text{total}} = 14 + 26 + 50 = 90\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the total equivalent resistance of three identical $150\,\Omega$ resistors when they are connected in parallel.
questions.explanation: For $n$ identical resistors in parallel, the equivalent resistance is $R_{\text{eq}} = \frac{R}{n} = \frac{150\,\Omega}{3} = 50\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Two $20\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in series. This combination is then connected in parallel with a single $40\,\Omega$ resistor. Find the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The series pair has a resistance of $20 + 20 = 40\,\Omega$. This $40\,\Omega$ resistor is in parallel with the other $40\,\Omega$ resistor. The equivalent resistance is given by $\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{40} + \frac{1}{40} = \frac{2}{40} = \frac{1}{20} \rightarrow R = 20\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Two $16\,\Omega$ resistors are connected in parallel. This combination is then connected in series with a $12\,\Omega$ resistor. Find the total equivalent resistance of this circuit.
questions.explanation: The parallel pair has an equivalent resistance of $\frac{16}{2} = 8\,\Omega$. Adding this in series with the $12\,\Omega$ resistor gives a total of $8 + 12 = 20\,\Omega$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the electrostatic force between two point charges of $2\,\mu\text{C}$ and $6\,\mu\text{C}$ separated by a distance of $0.02\text{ m}$ in a vacuum. (Use $k = 9 \times 10^9\text{ NÂ·m}^2/\text{C}^2$).
questions.explanation: Using Coulomb's Law, $F = k\frac{q_1 q_2}{r^2} = (9 \times 10^9)\frac{(2 \times 10^{-6})(6 \times 10^{-6})}{(0.02)^2} = \frac{108 \times 10^{-3}}{4 \times 10^{-4}} = 270\text{ N}$.

questions.question: If the distance between two point charges is tripled ($3r$), while the charges themselves remain unchanged, how does the magnitude of the electrostatic force between them change?
options: It becomes $1/3$ of the original force ($F/3$)
It becomes $1/9$ of the original force ($F/9$)
It becomes $1/27$ of the original force ($F/27$)
questions.explanation: Coulomb's Law states that force is inversely proportional to the square of the distance: $F \propto \frac{1}{r^2}$. Tripling the distance ($r \rightarrow 3r$) reduces the force by a factor of $3^2 = 9$, so the new force is $F/9$.

questions.question: Three point charges, A ($+q$), B ($+q$), and C ($-q$), are placed in a straight line with equal spacing between them. Charge A is on the left, B is in the middle, and C is on the right. What is the direction of the net electrostatic force on charge B?
options: Zero (the forces from A and C cancel out)
questions.explanation: Charge A ($+q$) repels charge B ($+q$) to the right. Charge C ($-q$) attracts charge B ($+q$) to the right. Both forces on B are in the same direction (to the right), so the net force on B is to the right.

questions.question: A $25\,\Omega$ resistor is connected to a $100\text{ V}$ power source. What current does it draw?
questions.explanation: Ohm's Law gives the current as $I = \frac{V}{R} = \frac{100\text{ V}}{25\,\Omega} = 4\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A $10\,\Omega$ heater has a current of $4\text{ A}$ flowing through it. What is the power dissipated by the heater?
questions.explanation: Electrical power can be calculated using $P = I^2R = (4\text{ A})^2 \times 10\,\Omega = 16 \times 10 = 160\text{ W}$.

questions.question: A $30\,\Omega$ resistor is connected to a $60\text{ V}$ power supply. Find the power dissipated by the resistor.
questions.explanation: Using the formula $P = \frac{V^2}{R}$, we get $P = \frac{(60\text{ V})^2}{30\,\Omega} = \frac{3{,}600}{30} = 120\text{ W}$.

questions.question: If a charge of $480\text{ C}$ flows through a conductor in a time of $4$ minutes, what is the current in the conductor?
questions.explanation: First convert time to seconds: $4$ minutes $= 240\text{ s}$. Electric current is $I = \frac{Q}{t} = \frac{480\text{ C}}{240\text{ s}} = 2\text{ A}$.

questions.question: A mechanical component has a width of $0.0084\text{ m}$. Express this width in millimeters (mm).
